monogr.title: Minucius Felix his dialogne [sic] called Octavius : Containing a defence of Christian religion. Translated by Richard Iames of C.C.C. Oxon
monogr.author: Minucius Felix, Marcus

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
WHosoeuer peruseth this litle booke or any other of auncient times, it behooues him to vse sobriety in his vnderstanding, least hee miscarry either in doctrine or discipline. For example, Minutius saith, the primitiue Christians had no Temples: you must not therefore collect, that wee ought to worship God only in fields or private houses. They had not indeed, Delubra, Temples of Jdolatry: wherein the Gentiles vsed as Prudentius hath it deasciato supplicare stipiti to make their orizons to a peece of hewd timber, yet as it is apparant out of all antiquitie, they had according to the sufferance
of times, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 houses built to the honour of our Lord and Saviour, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Cathedrall Churches: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , houses of prayer, oratories: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 stately piles of building, in which they did meete to solemnize the dutyes of Christianitie, and to heare the religious instructions of their prelates: More for the present I haue not to say. Let all things be done decently and in good order. This is a necessary remembrance from the Apostle, and so I wish the health of body and minde.
